title: What is an intuitive explanation of intuitive explanations? - Quora

response.answer_text: Referring to the question details: intuitive explanations aren’t necessarily condensed. Intuitive explanations are appealing because they meet you halfway, by conveying something useful in a way that’s not too hard to digest. Intuitive explanations might be oversimplified, or incomplete, or possibly even a little bit wrong. But they leave you better informed than no explanation, or an explanation that is correct but unintelligible. My most popular intuitive explanation on Quora is here: Michael Hochster's answer to What is an intuitive explanation of Bayes' Rule?. The answer is highly incomplete. It doesn’t even state Bayes’ rule! Or mention probability theory. It certainly doesn’t explain the role of Bayes’ rule as the foundation of all of Bayesian inference. But it does get one thing across: that you can use Bayes’ rule to find [math]P(B|A)[/math] when you know [math]P(A|B), P(A)[/math] and [math]P(B)[/math] (though I don’t use this notation). And it almost proves this, by working through a simple example. The example is almost a proof because you can see how it would go through if you replaced the specific numbers with some other ones. It would become a proof if the specific numbers were replaced with letters. But it’s often easier to understand a numerical example than the same idea expressed a little more generally. Maybe a bit paradoxically, a specific example sometimes gets the general idea across more clearly than the general idea expressed more directly. That’s one way intuitive explanations can work.

I’ll try to address this via an illustration. What is the motivation for the term "expectation" in the literature of Probability theory? Let’s say that we get our hands on an empirical average of the outcomes in a large experiment. This quantity is precisely what is referred to as the expectation. Some set up. Let [math]X[/math] be a discrete random variable (equivalent to saying, outcome of some random experiment) taking values in [math]\left\lbrace x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{m} \right\rbrace [/math]with [math] p_{i} = \mathbb{P}(X=x_{i})[/math](Probability that [math]X[/math] takes the value [math]x_i[/math]). Expectation of the random variable [math]X[/math] is [math]\sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{i}p_{i}.[/math] But how is this formula connected with the empirical average that we talked about earlier? In this regard read the following. Now conduct [math]N[/math] (where [math]N\gg m[/math]) independent trials of this above experiment mentioned. Let the sequence of outcomes be denoted as [math]{x^{(1)}, x^{(2)}, \ldots, x^{(N)}} [/math]. So with intuition we can say that, [math]x_{i}[/math] appears [math]Np_{i}[/math] times. Now, the arithmetic average is [math]\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N} x^{(j)}}{N}[/math]. Therefore, [math]\sum_{j=1}^{N} x^{(j)} \approx \sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{i}(Np_{i}).[/math] Equivalently, [math]\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N} x^{(j)}}{N} \approx \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{i}(Np_{i})}{N}[/math][math]= \sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{i}p_{i}.[/math] And so expected value of a random variable is thought as an empirical average of the outcomes in a large experiment.  Here knowing that the expectation of the random variable [math]X[/math] to be just by the formula [math]\sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{i}p_{i}[/math] doesn’t make sense unless one has an actual intuition (like the one explained above). Also look at Kishan Panaganti Badrinath (ಕಿಶನ್ ಪಾನಗಂಟಿ ಬದ್ರಿನಾಥ್)'s answer to What is an intuitive explanation of expected value?
